Award.AwardTitle: Support of the International Conference on Mesoscale Convective System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding enables the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research's (UCAR) Joint Office for Science Support (JOSS) to provide logistic support, partial travel support for US graduate students, transportation, as well as onsite support to the Tenth International Conference on Mesoscale Convective System (ICMCS-X)

Intellectual merit
The intellectual merit of this project is to enable the US graduate students to be prepared to address future scientific demands on high impact weather through the interactions with leading researchers in the US and East Asia countries. In addition, students will be exposed to new emerging technologies to sample and analyze these extreme weather events.

Broader impacts
High impact weather such as tropical cyclone and flooding events is one of the top research and operational priorities in the US in this rapidly changing climate environment. ICMCS-X will stimulate the intellectual curiosity of junior scientists and create a valuable international network to support their careers. This project will add to the resources to encouraging participation of US graduate students and benefit the educational community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This ICMCS-X conference attracted leading mesoscale and typhoon researchers in Asia to interact with US scientists and students, allowing US scientists to learn the hazardous weathers on the other side of the world and foster future scientific collaboration. This conference was held in Boulder, CO at UCAR's facilities during the month of September 2014. This conference also engaged many first time US participants and participants from non-traditional disciplines (e.g., geography and insurance industry). The entire conference program and presentations (agreed by authors) are posted on the web: http://icmcs.eawra.com.

 

I spoke to all 8 students who received group travel support during the conference. They were impressed with the quality of the presentation in this conference and appreciated NSF's support to enable them to interact with many US and international scientists. Some of them expressed that this conference was an eye opening experience to learn that the phenomena they worked on in the US were happening in other part of the world. 

 

 

 The travel support is provided to student presenters who presented their research at the conference. We provided up to $700 travel support to 8 US students.

 

 

Total participants: 110
US participants: 54
International participants: 56 (China, Taiwan, Japan, Korea, Canada, Australia)
